- Performance (línea 47)
- Using too many effects can cause poor performance, especially on mobile devices. Try to only (línea 48)
- use effects when it is important to the appearance of the game. (línea 49)
- Creating many instances of an object using effects can be very inefficient, since the effect must (línea 50)
- be processed repeatedly for small areas. If many instances need to use an effect, sometimes it (línea 51)
- is more efficient to place all the instances on their own layer, and apply the effect to that layer (línea 52)
- instead. This can improve performance whilst producing the same visual appearance. (línea 53)
- Never use effects to process a static effect on an object. For example, do not use the Grayscale (línea 54)
- effect to make an object always appear grayscale. Instead apply the grayscale effect in an image (línea 55)
- editor and import a grayscale image to the object, without using any effects. This has the same (línea 56)
- visual result, and avoids performance-degrading effect processing. Effects like Grayscale should (línea 57)
- only be used for transitions or making objects only occasionally appear grayscale. (línea 58)
- For more information, see the manual section on performance tips. (línea 59)

- Picking families in events (línea 135)
- Families pick instances in the event sheet independently of the object types in the family. For (línea 136)
- example, consider Family1 consisting of SpriteA and SpriteB. Conditions for Family1 will never (línea 137)
- affect which SpriteA and SpriteB instances are picked. It will only affect which instances are (línea 138)
- affected when running an action for Family1. Likewise, conditions picking SpriteA and SpriteB (línea 139)
- instances will never affect which instances are picked in Family1. In other words, in the event (línea 140)
- sheet families are treated like an entirely separate object type, which just happens to have (línea 141)
- instances from other object types. This can be taken advantage of if you need a single event to (línea 142)
- pick two separate lists of instances from the same object type. (línea 143)

- Summary (línea 150)
- Families are a very powerful feature which are essential to help keep large projects simple. (línea 151)
- Instance variables and behaviors added to families are inherited by every object in the family, (línea 152)
- which allows for sophisticated logic to be easily applied to many object types at once. (línea 153)

- event sheets, whereas hierarchies generally apply to making objects move and rotate (línea 169)

- BREAKPOINTS (línea 257)
- Paid plans only Breakpoints are an advanced feature that allow you to pause execution of the (línea 260)
- event sheet on a specific event, condition or action when running in the debugger. This can be a (línea 261)
- significant aid to debugging, since the full capabilities of the debugger can be used while (línea 262)
- stepping through events, conditions and actions one-by-one. (línea 263)
- Setting a breakpoint (línea 265)
- Breakpoints can be toggled on and off for the selected event block, condition or action by rightclicking them and selecting Toggle breakpoint or pressing the F3 keyboard shortcut. Breakpoints (línea 266)
- can also be toggled while debugging. (línea 267)
- When a breakpoint is set on an event, condition or action, a breakpoint icon appears beside it. (línea 268)
- Pausing on a breakpoint (línea 270)
- When running the debugger, the project will automatically pause just before it runs an event, (línea 271)
- condition or action with a breakpoint. (línea 272)
- For events, this means it pauses just before it tests the first condition. This means a top-level (línea 273)
- event with a breakpoint will pause every tick, since the event engine reaches it every tick to test (línea 274)
- its conditions. It is usually more useful to place event breakpoints on sub-events, since they will (línea 275)
- only pause when the parent events have been run. When paused on a breakpoint, the event has a (línea 276)
- dashed outline and the icon changes to an arrow. (línea 277)
- For conditions, this means it pauses just before it tests the condition. Since the condition has (línea 279)
- you must resume execution to be able to tell. Note that Construct bails out of events early if any (línea 281)
- the first condition is false, since Construct will immediately skip to checking the next event. (línea 288)
- When paused on a condition, it is also indicated with a dashed outline, an arrow and also a (línea 289)
- changed background color. (línea 290)
- For actions, this means it pauses just before the action runs. Placing a breakpoint on the first (línea 292)
- action in an event is often more useful than placing a breakpoint on the event itself, since it will (línea 293)
- only pause when all the conditions have been met and before any actions have run, as opposed (línea 294)
- to just before it starts checking any conditions. When paused on an action, it is indicated (línea 295)
- similarly to a condition. (línea 296)
- Continuing execution (línea 298)
- When paused on a breakpoint, the debugger can be used as normal to inspect or edit values. (línea 299)
- However the Pause and Step buttons change in to Continue and Next. (línea 300)
- Pressing Continue resumes until the next breakpoint is hit. Remember you can still toggle other (línea 301)
- breakpoints while paused on a breakpoint. (línea 302)
- Pressing Next will step to the next event, condition or action in sequence in the event sheet. (línea 303)
- Alternatively, press F10 with the browser window focused. This is useful for stepping through an (línea 304)
- Limitations (línea 307)
- Unfortunately due to the architecture of the Construct engine, breakpoints cannot be placed (línea 308)
- inside some (but not all) triggered events. When not supported, this also means breakpoints (línea 309)
- cannot be anywhere inside sub-events to the triggered event. (línea 310)
- Using breakpoints (línea 312)
- Breakpoints can be incredibly useful to learn more about how your own events work and to help (línea 313)
- track down problems. They may take some getting used to in order to get the most out of them, (línea 314)
- but once familiar they can be indispensable. (línea 315)
- It is especially useful to have a multi-monitor setup when using breakpoints, or with the (línea 321)
- debugger in general. This allows you to have Construct showing which event it has reached on (línea 322)
- one screen, and the project running on another screen. (línea 323)

- COMMON CONVENTIONS (línea 237)
- For consistency, Construct usually uses some common conventions in how values are used. (línea 240)
- These are described below. (línea 241)
- Common units (línea 243)
- In Construct, sometimes you need to enter values such as angles, speeds or sizes. For (línea 244)
- consistency these always use the same units in Construct, except where noted by descriptions (línea 245)
- or tips shown in the editor. The common units are described below. (línea 246)
- Positions are in pixels. The origin (0,0) is at the top-left of the layout, and the Y axis (línea 247)
- increments downwards (as is often the case with game engines). (línea 248)
- Sizes are in pixels (línea 249)
- Angles are in degrees. 0 degrees faces right and increments clockwise. (línea 250)
- Times are in seconds (línea 251)
- Speeds are in pixels per second (línea 252)
- Accelerations are in pixels per second per second (línea 253)
- Zero-based indexing (línea 255)
- To be consistent with programming languages, all features of Construct using a number of an (línea 256)
- item in a list (indices) start from 0 instead of 1. This might seem odd at first and take some (línea 257)
- getting used to, but in many cases it is actually much more convenient than 1-based indexing. (línea 258)
- Traditionally lists are numbered 1, 2, 3... but in Construct (and all other programming languages) (línea 259)
- they are numbered 0, 1, 2.... (línea 260)
- Ranges (línea 262)
- Sometimes the documentation will refer to ranges of valid values. These are in square brackets (línea 263)
- For example valid values in this range are 0, 0.5, and 1. A round bracket indicates a non-inclusive (línea 265)
- including 1. For example valid values in this range are 0, 0.5 and 0.999, but not 1. (línea 267)

- Performance overhead (línea 157)
- As illustrated, for each layer which you make a HTML layer, an additional canvas element is (línea 162)
- created at the size of the viewport. This comes with a performance overhead. It will impact two (línea 163)
- aspects of performance: (línea 164)
- Each canvas must be copied to the display every frame. This has the effect of drawing a (línea 167)
- viewport-sized surface, much like a Force own texture layer. This uses up the GPU fill rate (see (línea 168)
- Performance Tips for more details about fill rate). In some cases the compositing process may (línea 169)
- require more than one copy, making it potentially two or three times as costly as a Force own (línea 170)
- texture layer. (línea 171)
- Each canvas must be allocated in memory, which will use at least as much memory as a (línea 175)
- viewport-sized image. For example a 1920x1080 size canvas will require at least 8 MB of (línea 176)
- memory (see Memory usage for more details). In some cases the compositing process may (línea 177)
- require more than one surface, making it potentially use two or three times as much memory. (línea 178)
- For this reason, avoid using too many HTML layers. Try to use the minimum necessary number (línea 180)
- of HTML layers to achieve the layering you need for your project. (línea 181)
- Positioning (línea 183)
- HTML objects use a size and position based on the Construct layer they are on. In other words (línea 184)
- they match the size and position that they would have if they were a canvas object. Therefore if (línea 185)
- HTML objects are on layers with different scroll positions, scales, or parallax, they will match the (línea 186)
- position of the layer they are on, even though they are displayed on the next HTML layer above (línea 187)
- them. (línea 188)

- You may find that if you move both canvas objects and HTML objects simultaneously at high (línea 190)

- two, due to the browser drawing them at different times. (línea 192)

- Physics behavior stepping mode (línea 839)
- In Construct 2, the Physics behavior defaulted to fixed stepping mode. This meant simulations (línea 840)
- were deterministic, but also meant it assumed a fixed display rate of 60 Hz. This was a (línea 841)

- monitors with 144Hz+ displays. On these devices the fixed framerate mode of the Physics (línea 844)
- behavior appears to run in fast-forward mode. (línea 845)
- To avoid this, the Physics behavior in Construct 3 instead defaults to framerate independent (línea 846)
- mode. This ensures it works at the same speed on all displays, but means the simulation is no (línea 847)
- longer deterministic. If you want to restore a deterministic simulation you can use the Set (línea 848)

- pause while loading is done). In the C3 runtime, in this case the game continues to run and the (línea 855)
- images are loaded in parallel. This provides better loading performance and avoids janking the (línea 856)
- game. However the object can exist for a short period of time while the images are still being (línea 857)
- loaded. During this time the object is not drawn, as if it were set to invisible. In some cases this (línea 863)
- can cause a noticable flicker, especially if the object is intended to cover up something else. The (línea 864)
- workaround is to place the object in the layout, and destroy it in On start of layout if it is not (línea 865)
- needed. This ensures Construct loads its images when loading the layout, avoiding any delay (línea 866)
- when creating it. (línea 867)

- CUSTOM MOVEMENT BEHAVIOR (línea 253)
- The Custom Movement behavior does not directly implement any movement for an object. (línea 256)
- movement. (línea 258)
- The way different movements are made is out of the scope of this manual section. Instead, it will (línea 259)
- outline the basics of the Custom Movement behavior and what its features do. For an example (línea 260)
- of Asteroids style movement using the Custom Movement behavior, open the Custom movement (línea 261)
- For many games, the built-in behaviors like Platform and 8 Direction are perfectly sufficient. (línea 263)
- Recreating existing behaviors with the Custom Movement should be avoided, since movements (línea 264)
- are difficult and time consuming to implement correctly. The built-in behaviours have been (línea 265)
- thoroughly tested, probably have more features than you imagine (like slope detection in (línea 266)
- Platform), and are much quicker and easier to use than making your own movement. (línea 267)
- Overview of custom movements (línea 269)
- Most movements in Construct work by manipulating two values: the speed on the X axis (dx) (línea 270)
- and the speed on the Y axis (dy). These are also known as VectorX and VectorY in some other (línea 271)
- behaviors. For example, if an object is moving left at 100 pixels per second, dx is -100 and dy is (línea 272)
- 0. The object can then be accelerated to the right by adding to dx. This is also how most of the (línea 273)
- other movement behaviors that come with Construct work internally (like Platform and 8 (línea 274)
- Direction). (línea 275)
- The Custom Movement behavior stores the dx and dy values for you, and provides features that (línea 276)
- help easily implement the math and algorithms necessary to make a movement. (línea 277)
- This is called a step. The Custom Movement can also use multiple steps per tick, which can help (línea 279)
- detect collisions more accurately if the object is moving very quickly. Each step will trigger On (línea 280)
- step, On horizontal step or On vertical step depending on the Stepping mode property. (línea 281)
- Custom Movement properties (línea 283)
- Stepping mode (línea 284)
- How to step the movement each tick. The number of steps taken (if not None) depends on (línea 286)
- the Pixels per step property. The different modes are: (línea 287)
- None simply steps the object once per tick according to its velocity. (línea 288)
- Linear will step the object in a straight line towards its destination position, triggering On (línea 294)
- step. (línea 295)
- Horizontal then vertical will step the object to its destination first on the X axis (línea 296)
- Vertical then horizontal will step the object to its destination first on the Y axis (línea 298)
- Pixels per step (línea 300)
- If Stepping mode is not None, this is the distance in pixels of each step towards the (línea 302)
- destination position each tick. The default is 5, which means if the object is moving 20 pixels (línea 303)
- in a tick, it will move in four five-pixel steps. (línea 304)

- DESTROY OUTSIDE LAYOUT (línea 422)
- BEHAVIOR (línea 423)
- The Destroy Outside Layout behavior simply automatically destroys an object if it leaves the (línea 426)
- layout area. It only destroys the object if it is entirely outside the layout (i.e. no part of its (línea 427)
- bounding box is inside the layout). The Destroy Outside Layout behavior has no properties, (línea 428)
- conditions, actions or expressions. (línea 429)
- This behavior is often useful to prevent bullets and other projectiles flying off the layout forever. (línea 430)
- For example, without this behavior, if the user shoots some enemies and misses, the bullets (línea 431)
- could carry on flying off outside the layout forever. As the game goes on, more and more bullets (línea 432)
- build up over time, all moving further away forever. This gradually uses up more and more (línea 433)
- memory and CPU power causing the game to slow down. This can easily be avoided by adding (línea 434)
- this behavior to the bullets, so they are automatically removed when they leave the layout area. (línea 435)

- Fades run in the following order. If any of the times are 0, the step is skipped. (línea 509)
- The object fades in from invisible to its set opacity, over the Fade in time. (línea 512)
- The object remains at its current opacity for the Wait time. (línea 516)
- The object fades out to invisible, over the Fade out time. (línea 520)

- The pathfinding grid (línea 131)
- The pathfinding behavior works based on dividing the layout in to a grid. Since pixel-perfect (línea 132)
- pathfinding can be extremely slow to process, dividing the layout in to cells makes the (línea 133)
- pathfinding enormously more efficient. The cell size can be set in the behavior property, and the (línea 134)
- larger it is the more efficient pathfinding is. However setting a large cell size can cause (línea 135)
- problems: a cell can only be entirely obstacle or entirely free, and using large cells can close up (línea 136)
- small gaps. For example take the following arrangement of obstacles using a cell size of 32: (línea 137)
- It appears that objects should be able to freely move around in between these objects. However (línea 139)
- if the cells that the pathfinding behavior marks as obstacle are highlighted in red, we see this: (línea 140)
- Some of the gaps have been closed off due to the cell size being relatively large compared to the (línea 146)
- size of the gap. This will make the pathfinding behavior route paths entirely around the (línea 147)
- obstacles, and never through them. We can help fix this by reducing the cell size to 20: (línea 148)
- Now we can see that the Pathfinding behavior will be able to find routes between these (línea 150)
- obstacles. However, the smaller cell size will make the pathfinding more CPU intensive. (línea 151)
- Generally, try to use the largest cell size that does not cause problems navigating around (línea 152)
- obstacles. (línea 153)
- The Cell border property can adjust how cells are marked as obstacle. If the border is larger than (línea 154)
- 0, then cells close to obstacles but not actually touching may also be marked as obstacles, (línea 155)
- obstacle may not be marked as an obstacle, effectively shrinking the obstacle area inwards. The (línea 157)
- image below demonstrates the effect of different cell border values when using a cell size of 20. (línea 158)
- For best efficiency, use the same cell size and border for all objects using the Pathfinding (línea 160)

- SOLID BEHAVIOR (línea 216)
- The Solid behavior makes other behaviors react to the object as if it were an impassable (línea 219)
- obstacle. Objects with this behavior are referred to as Solids. It affects the following behaviors: (línea 220)
- 8 Direction, which is blocked by Solids (línea 221)
- Bullet, which can optionally bounce off Solids (línea 222)
- Car, which bounces off Solids (línea 223)
- Line-of-sight, which by default has line-of-sight obstructed by Solids (línea 224)
- Move To, which can optionally stop on solids. (línea 225)
- Platform, which can land on Solids. Platform cannot jump on to solids from underneath - for (línea 226)
- this, use the Jump-thru behavior. (línea 227)
- Pathfinding, which by default uses solids as path obstacles. (línea 228)
- Tile movement, which is blocked by Solids (línea 229)
- Note that the Physics behavior is not affected by Solid objects. Instead, use the Physics behavior (línea 230)
- with Immovable enabled. (línea 231)
- The Solid behavior is a fundamental attribute in Construct, and several other Construct features (línea 232)
- also interact with Solid objects. For example, the Custom Movement behavior has actions to (línea 233)
- push the object out of solids. (línea 234)

- moving Solid objects. You should be especially careful when moving Solids up against other (línea 248)
- Solids. (línea 249)

- Predictive aim (línea 553)
- A useful feature of the Turret behavior is the ability to use predictive aim. For an interactive (línea 554)
- demonstration of this see the Turret predictive aim example in the Start dialog. (línea 555)
- Normally turrets aim directly at a target. This often means moving targets are never hit, because (línea 556)
- by the time the projectile arrives, the object has moved somewhere else. Predictive aim solves (línea 557)
- this by aiming the turret at where the object will be by the time the projectile arrives, if it (línea 558)
- maintains the same velocity. In order for this to work, the Turret behavior must have the speed of (línea 559)
- the projectile set in its Projectile speed property, so it can determine how long it will take for the (línea 560)
- projectile to arrive. The projectile must also use a fixed speed, and not have any acceleration or (línea 566)
- deceleration. (línea 567)
- It is still possible for targets to dodge predictive aiming turrets, by changing direction or speed (línea 568)
- while the projectile travels towards it. However this is considerably more difficult compared to (línea 569)
- not using predictive aim, and the overall accuracy of the turret will be significantly improved. (línea 570)

- random numbers. For example if you add three items with a weight of 1, and then a fourth item (línea 938)

- probability table entry can be either a number or a string, but the weight must be a number. This (línea 940)
- is useful for doing things like random pickups with lots of common cheap items, but also some (línea 941)
- rare valuable items. (línea 942)
- Permutation tables (línea 944)

- sequence of numbers that are randomly ordered. This is useful for retrieving random, nonrepeating numbers. For example you could use the numbers 0-51 to represent a deck of cards, (línea 950)
- and create a permutation table to represent a shuffled deck of cards. Then if you read through (línea 951)
- the permutation table in order with the Permutation expression, it will return a random sequence (línea 952)

- Handling resizing and resolution (línea 411)
- The Drawing Canvas object has two ways of handling the resolution of the canvas, each with (línea 412)
- their own advantages and disadvantages. (línea 413)
- Automatic resolution mode (línea 415)
- By default, the canvas uses automatic resolution mode, which uses the same display resolution (línea 416)
- as the game. However the display resolution usually changes when the window is resized. For (línea 417)
- example in letterbox scale mode, when the window is resized larger the game displays the same (línea 418)
- content but at a larger size (using more pixels). A similar thing happens when you resize the (línea 419)
- object itself. The Drawing canvas object automatically changes the resolution of its canvas when (línea 420)
- this happens. This is destructive, though: the next draw to the canvas will clear it, because (línea 421)
- internally the drawing surface is destroyed and recreated at the new resolution. The advantage (línea 422)
- of this approach is it ensures drawn content will appear with high quality, as resizing or scaling (línea 423)
- will increase the resolution, rather than stretching a lower resolution image. (línea 424)
- The reason it waits until the next draw to recreate the drawing surface is so that if you draw to it (línea 425)
- once, the same content is simply displayed stretched at the new resolution. This is often an (línea 426)
- acceptable result after drawing in On start of layout. Normally a better idea is to draw one-off (línea 427)
- content in the trigger On resolution changed - this also triggers on startup, and again any time (línea 432)
- the resolution changes, ensuring your content can increase in detail if the window is resized (línea 433)
- larger. (línea 434)
- Alternatively if you clear and re-render the canvas in Every tick, since it is always redrawing it will (línea 435)
- always draw at the current resolution. This approach is similar to how the runtime itself renders, (línea 436)
- although you may want to stop drawing if nothing is changing in the game, which is also what (línea 437)
- the runtime does. (línea 438)
- Fixed resolution mode (línea 440)
- Another option is to use a fixed resolution. This defaults to using the size of the object as the (línea 441)
- size of the drawing surface (i.e. if the object is 100x100 in the layout, then the drawing surface (línea 442)
- will be 100x100 pixels too). The drawing surface can also be set to a different size using the Set (línea 443)
- resolution mode action. (línea 444)
- Fixed resolution mode will keep the drawing surface at the same resolution regardless of the (línea 445)
- object size, window size, or scale. In other words it will always use the same size surface and (línea 446)
- just stretch it to fit the display. The advantage of this is it will preserve the drawn content even as (línea 447)
- the display resolution changes. However a potential downside is as it does not increase quality (línea 448)
- as the resolution increases, in some cases it could appear blurry or pixellated. (línea 449)
- Co-ordinate systems (línea 451)
- The Drawing canvas object allows you to draw shapes and lines at specific positions. In (línea 452)
- automatic resolution mode it uses a co-ordinate system relative to the object in layout coordinates. For example if the object is sized 100x100 in the layout, then the point (50, 50) is (línea 453)
- change the drawing co-ordinates depending on the canvas resolution: everything scales (línea 455)
- automatically, so if the user resizes the window larger, content automatically increases in detail. (línea 456)
- In fixed resolution mode the co-ordinate system is instead in pixels on the drawing surface. For (línea 457)
- example if the drawing surface is 100x100, then the point (50, 50) is in the middle, regardless of (línea 458)
- the size or scale of the Drawing Canvas object. (línea 459)
- Note that when using snapshots to read and write pixel data, snapshot pixels are given in (línea 460)
- actual pixel co-ordinates rather than object co-ordinates, even in automatic resolution mode. (línea 461)
- The PixelScale expression also gives the size of an actual pixel on the drawing surface in (línea 462)
- object co-ordinates, allowing you to convert between object and pixel co-ordinates. (línea 463)
- Pixel manipulation with snapshots (línea 465)
- The way computer graphics works makes requesting to retrieve the color of even just a single (línea 466)
- pixel an extremely costly operation. Rendering is highly optimised to go one way: sending (línea 467)
- drawing commands from the CPU, rendering on the GPU, and then displaying the result on the (línea 468)
- the system has to wait for the result, it would completely stall the rendering process, almost (línea 474)
- certainly janking the framerate. (línea 475)
- In order to avoid the performance pitfalls while allowing access to individual pixels, the Drawing (línea 476)
- canvas object uses a snapshot system, which works like this: (línea 477)
- The Save snapshot action copies the entire canvas image on the GPU. (línea 480)
- The copied image is then sent asynchronously (in parallel) back to the CPU. Rendering can (línea 484)
- continue while this happens. (línea 485)
- When the copied image is available on the CPU, On snapshot triggers. Now the pixel data can be (línea 489)
- read using the snapshot expressions, e.g. SnapshotRedAt(x, y). (línea 490)
- If the pixel data needs to be altered, it can be modified using the Set snapshot pixel action. This (línea 494)
- only changes the copy available to the CPU and does not visibly affect the canvas. To make (línea 495)
- changes visible, use the Load snapshot action, which copies the snapshot back to the canvas. (línea 496)
- The Noise textures example demonstrates how to do this, writing random pixel data generated (línea 498)
- by the Advanced Random object. (línea 499)

- Signalling and hosting (línea 979)

- connection information like IP addresses. Players must connect and log in to the signalling (línea 983)
- server before they can join any rooms. (línea 984)
- The first player in to a room becomes the host. The host acts as the server for the game, (línea 985)

- multiplayer game. (línea 988)

- to work in a background tab). Note this means your server is genuinely running the game - as (línea 994)
- mentioned, the signalling server only helps peers connect to the room host, and actual gameplay (línea 995)
- data will be transmitted through your server if it is the room host. It is not necessary to run your (línea 996)

- Sending messages (línea 1010)
- Peers only connect to the host. In other words, the host has a connection to every peer, and (línea 1011)
- peers only have one connection to the host. In order for two peers to communicate, the (línea 1012)
- information must be relayed via the host. (línea 1013)

- message the host. See the chat tutorial for an example of how to relay messages through the (línea 1015)
- host so other peers can receive messages from another peer. (línea 1016)
- The host also has the unique ability to broadcast a message. This sends the same message to (línea 1017)
- every peer in the room. (línea 1018)
- Messages can be sent with different reliability modes. These are: (línea 1019)
- Reliable ordered: all messages are guaranteed to arrive, and the order received will be the (línea 1020)
- same as the order sent. However this can have the highest latency since a lost message will (línea 1021)
- need retransmitting and will hold up every message sent after it. This mode is suitable for (línea 1022)
- chat messages. (línea 1023)
- Reliable unordered: all messages are guaranteed to arrive, but the order received can be (línea 1024)
- different from the order sent. This allows improved latency since a lost message will be held (línea 1025)
- up as it is retransmitted, but subsequent messages can still get through quickly without (línea 1026)
- being held up. This mode is suitable for gameplay events that occur independently of each (línea 1027)
- Unreliable: messages are not guaranteed to arrive, and the order received can be different (línea 1029)
- but the message may be dropped and the recipient will never receive it and will have no (línea 1031)
- indication it was even attempted to be sent. This mode is suitable for high-bandwidth or (línea 1032)
- regularly-sent messages, where if a message is dropped it is likely to be shortly followed up (línea 1033)
- by another one. Note the Multiplayer object uses this mode internally for object positions and (línea 1034)

- have hard edges. If the radius is larger, it accurately renders penumbras (the transition from (línea 211)

- Shadow limitations (línea 215)
- Due to the shadow rendering algorithm, there are a couple of limitations: (línea 216)
- The shadow casters can only use convex collision polygons. Shadows will not render (línea 217)
- correctly if they use concave polygons. If you need a concave shape, this can always be (línea 218)
- achieved by placing multiple shadow caster objects next to each other to compose a (línea 224)
- concave shape out of convex parts. (línea 225)
- Antumbras (beyond where the umbra converges to a point) are not rendered. To avoid the (línea 226)
- umbra converging to a point on-screen, avoid using shadow casters smaller than the light (línea 227)
- radius. Stick to large shadow casters and a small light radius. (línea 228)
- When using a light radius, avoid placing the light very close to or directly over a shadow (línea 229)
- caster. Shadows can fail to render correctly in these circumstances. (línea 230)
- Tags (línea 232)
- By default, all shadow lights cast shadows off all shadow casters. In some cases it is desirable (línea 233)
- to only have certain shadow lights cast shadows off certain shadow caster objects. Each (línea 234)
- shadow light object can be assigned a tag, and the Cast from property set to only cast shadows (línea 235)

- Light radius (línea 244)
- The radius of the light. If the radius is 0, the light acts like a point source and shadows are (línea 246)

- offscreen. (línea 251)

- TOUCH (línea 174)
- The Touch object detects input from touchscreen devices like phones and tablets, as well as (línea 177)
- desktops or laptops with touch-sensitive displays. (línea 178)
- The Touch object also provides input from the accelerometer (motion) and inclinometer (línea 179)
- some low-end devices lack the necessary hardware to measure these values. (línea 182)
- It is best to support touch input wherever possible. On the web many users browse on mobile (línea 183)
- devices with touch input only and no mouse or keyboard. If your project does not support touch (línea 184)
- controls, many users will be unable to play your project at all. For a guide on how to implement (línea 185)
- on-screen touch controls, see the tutorial on Touch controls. (línea 186)
- For a number of examples of using Touch input, search for Touch in the Example Browser. (línea 187)

- Multi-touch (línea 193)

- touching object conditions, which can for example detect if multiple on-screen touch controls are (línea 195)
- being used. This is sufficient for many projects. (línea 196)
- For more advanced uses, the TouchID, XForID and YForID expressions can be used to track (línea 197)
- individual touches for different purposes. Each touch has a unique ID (which is an arbitrary (línea 198)
- number), and can be accessed using the TouchID expression in an event like On any touch start. (línea 199)
- The touch ID can then be stored in a variable and tracked using the XForID and YForID (línea 200)
- expressions. Finally comparing the TouchID in On any touch end indicates when that touch has (línea 201)
- been released. (línea 202)

- This can be very useful for testing touch events work properly on a desktop computer with (línea 209)
- no touch input supported. However, only single-touch input can be simulated with a mouse, (línea 210)
- and a mouse is much more precise than a touch, so it is still best to test on a real (línea 216)
